Does anyone else have a low opinion of rxjava? For all the time it saves it burns me chasing down issues that the documentation makes difficult to understand. That combined with how hard it is to debug many elements of it, I'm starting to feel that using it for threading is foolish.

Creating lots of custom schedulers is the best answer for how to fine control it which you have to do when normally with threading but that just leads you to often use scheduler's you didn't really need and the then of course make sure you transport work to the right threads. Lastly it convolutes when things need to be volatile or atomic since knowing how some object will be used isn't necessarily always known. Immutable objects are a partial answer but now I just design everything knowing Rx might be called in a way I didn't expect future eating into whatever time savings it supposedly nets me.
And missing back pressure exceptions can go die
I don't think I've ever created a custom Scheduler
Die a horrible death
nor have I worried about volatile/atomic stuff
I've had to for several things
Like calling a system binary. Call it from too many threads and it blows up
Other times certain things have ended up emiting data too fast so flatmaps burn you randomly in a very difficult to test or replicate manner

That leads to more custom schedulers or alternatively you can do buffering but the reality is the back pressure issue is the problem in many cases as I have finite data sets that can emit very fast sometimes but it will end and Rx just assumes the worst far too quickly

With volatile and atomic that is issues with classes that need an internal state. I can either put synchro locks on all the methods or hope only the right thread calls it or create a scheduler so it has its own dedicated thread to ensure nothing is done out of order
With simple stuff Rx is fine just like lambdas
No complaints there. I just think any time you are using flatmap, schedule on, or observe on.. you are possibly unknowingly shooting yourself
I have yet to actually use rxjava
I make heavy usage of promises though
Maybe we are using Rx wrong but either way I'm tired of googling issues and not ever being confident that a fix is a fix or just another trap I haven't yet tripped
for the small use-cases ive implemented it for (networking/basic database functions), it’s been pretty useful - no idea about more sophisticated  use-cases like you’ve mentioned
<@U055GGAHS> How do you create your observables?
<@U055GGAHS> can you post an example use case?
No I can't post an example
I would have to come up with a contrived example which would be complicated
In what scenario would the data emit to fast for a flatmap?
I only ask because I have made heavy use of flatmap and haven't noticed any problems but maybe my use is simple compared
Like pulling 1000 items from a database which you need to process asynchronously. And the results of that produce more work and so on
Think database to processing to database to UI. Generally
Ye, i am doing the same thing but I have yet to test it on 1000 items
I assumed if it worked with a few it would scale up, probably a bad assumption on my part

Due to various os limitations the processing has to be done on only a few threads at a time. Due to this a lot of flatmap ops can be queued up then the output causes more flatmaps and a few calls of that at the same time causes back pressure exceptions sometimes
We assumed that too
I see
It worked fine until it didn't and good luck debugging it
I'm worried now
Because you cant
There is a debugging library specifically for Rx
not sure how useful it is
I Had to go comment out code until I could narrow it down but since it's not consistent that was a real time waste
ye that doesn't sound good, I will have to do a proper test tomorrow
So really when it comes to threading I think at least Rx 1 is not good
Oh your using rx1?
I don't know if Rx 2 really helps with this issue
Well it was completely rewritten in RxJava 2.0
they aimed to solve backpresure problems

A small regret about introducing backpressure in RxJava 0.x is that instead of having a separate base reactive class, the Observable itself was retrofitted. The main issue with backpressure is that many hot sources, such as UI events, can't be reasonably backpressured and cause unexpected MissingBackpressureException (i.e., beginners don't expect them).

We try to remedy this situation in 2.x by having io.reactivex.Observable non-backpressured and the new io.reactivex.Flowable be the backpressure-enabled base reactive class.

When to use Observable

You have a flow of no more than 1000 elements at its longest: i.e., you have so few elements over time that there is practically no chance for OOME in your application.

When to use Flowable

Dealing with 10k+ of elements that are generated in some fashion somewhere and thus the chain can tell the source to limit the amount it generates.
Yeah no I've read that but we can't swap out Rx libs for a bit
I see
We are already in production so it's hard to make sweeping changes like that
Ye I understand, I should be ok though :stuck_out_tongue:
Maybe
It's not easy to test
ye, I don't think I will be dealing with that many items at once anyway
at least not at first
So random question
I want to have my code wait a given amount of time
I am writing an android things app
and I want the equivalent of arduino `delay(1000);`
sleep?
Thread.sleep() if I'm not mistaken
would this explode if it were done inside of a handler?
Based on which looper your handler run

<@U08GFT5V5> why not just post to another runner at the specified time?
the handler thread already has 'sleep' built into it via the timing
it’s not very high precision though
Or you can use Rx and use delay :wink:
It doesn’t need to be precise
I really only need on “hw” loop going
So I put the whole thing in a runnable, posted and use sleep to delay
It’s proof of concept sh*t
not production code
gotcha
you can use postDelayed as an alternative
obviously the error in the delay will be worst case the longest duration of your slowest runnable
typically that’s just a few ms
Yeah I actually needed to delay inside the running loop

wait 40 microseconds
Set cursor to bit 8
wait 80 microseconds

I worked on a project where we managed to finish ahead of schedule and under budget, that became a big issue and we ended up coming up with new ‘addon at no cost’ work to validate the price of the program. At the end they ended up giving us more money for more addon work which was also completed ahead of schedule and under budget repeating the cycle of confusion then needing to invent more work to fill the budget

the government guys where literally angry because us completing ahead of schedule and under budget potentially causes a *lot* of paperwork which is unacceptable and since we hit that mark they had to go to the military customers and ask for ‘extra’ work to add to the program to validate the schedule and budget.

this is how :flag-us: works

attachments.title: KFC in Japan
attachments.text:
KFC (the name was originally an initialism for Kentucky Fried Chicken) is a fast food restaurant chain that specializes in fried chicken and is headquartered in Louisville, Kentucky, United States (US). It is the world's second largest restaurant chain (as measured by sales) after McDonald's, with 18,875 outlets in 118 countries and territories as of December 2013. The company is a subsidiary of Yum! Brands, a restaurant company that also owns the Pizza Hut and Taco Bell chains.
Japan is the third-largest market for KFC after China and the United States with 1,165 outlets as of December 2014. In Japan, 70 percent of sales are take-away, with customers tending to buy fried chicken for parties and other special occasions and eating it as a side dish.

text: >From December 1974, KFC Japan began to promote fried chicken as a Christmas meal, with its long running "Kentucky for Christmas" (Japanese: クリスマスはケンタッキー) advertising campaign.[4] Eating KFC as a Christmas time meal has since become a widely practised custom in Japan.[5][6][7]
